paragraphs.text:
%md
### Python tutorial: Cleaning, Preparing and Wrangling Data made **easy** with the Sparkling.Data library
In this notebook, we will analyse a drug dataset to understand what factors in each patients history led to them responding well to one specific drug over others. 

For our analysis, we start with our data set which contains data about 30 patients -- all of whom suffered from the same illness.  Each of these patients responded well to one of five medications. We want use a decision tree to analyze the dataset. However, our dataset is not yet clean and ready for analyzis. It has been stored as multiple files, so reading the files in is not as simple. Moreover, it might contain missing/bad data which we need to be cleaned, and transformed. Finally, we should identify the data type of each variable and form the schema of dataframe.

Our focus in this tutorial is to show you how easily read, clean and prepare your data for analysis. Specifically, we will: 
1. Read drug data files from a given directory 
2. Discover data types
3. Reveal bad data and then fix bad data  
4. Run profile on cleaned data  
5. Save results to a file
6. Analyze your prepared dataset

In the last step, we will use our cleaned dataset to analyze and understand what factors in each patients history led to them responding well to one specific medication over the others. The decision tree can generate a set of evidence-based rules or policies that can be followed by doctors to treat this illness in future patients. We will also explore how to interpret decision trees.

result.msg:
Python tutorial: Cleaning, Preparing and Wrangling Data made easy with the Sparkling.Data library

In this notebook, we will analyse a drug dataset to understand what factors in each patients history led to them responding well to one specific drug over others.

For our analysis, we start with our data set which contains data about 30 patients – all of whom suffered from the same illness. Each of these patients responded well to one of five medications. We want use a decision tree to analyze the dataset. However, our dataset is not yet clean and ready for analyzis. It has been stored as multiple files, so reading the files in is not as simple. Moreover, it might contain missing/bad data which we need to be cleaned, and transformed. Finally, we should identify the data type of each variable and form the schema of dataframe.

Our focus in this tutorial is to show you how easily read, clean and prepare your data for analysis. Specifically, we will:

  1. Read drug data files from a given directory
  2. Discover data types
  3. Reveal bad data and then fix bad data
  4. Run profile on cleaned data
  5. Save results to a file
  6. Analyze your prepared dataset

In the last step, we will use our cleaned dataset to analyze and understand what factors in each patients history led to them responding well to one specific medication over the others. The decision tree can generate a set of evidence-based rules or policies that can be followed by doctors to treat this illness in future patients. We will also explore how to interpret decision trees.

paragraphs.title: Import The Necessary Sparkling.Data Library
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
from pyspark.sql import SQLContext
sqlContext = SQLContext(sc)
from extension_utils import ExtensionUtils
eu = ExtensionUtils(sqlContext)

%md
# 1. Read drug data files

### Drug dataset
As can be seen, the data set contains information about the age and gender of each patient along with Blood Pressure, Cholesterol, Sodium and Potassium levels.  Finally, we have information about the drug the patient responded well to.

The dataset is in the form of two _json_ files, stored in a directory. The first json file is related to year 2014, and the second one is for year 2015. You can download the json files from [here](https://ibm.box.com/shared/static/9nxnsf6xwmuczjea911xjxp8l21yyd2x.zip)

Here is a sample row of druginfo2015.json:
>{    "Ent#":12,    "Age":34,    "Gender":"F",    "BP":"HIGH",    "Cholesterol":"NORMAL",    "Sodium":0.667775,    "Potassium":0.034782,    "Drug":"drugY",    "Cost":"1.981,09",    "DateTested":"1980-10-11T10:10:20"  }

Variables in the data set are :

- **Ent#** which represents patient ID  
- **Age** of each patient   
- **Gender** of each patient  
- **BP** - Blood Pressure of each patient  
- **Cholesterol** levels  
- **Sodium** levels  
- **Potassium** levels  
- **Drug** the patient responded well to  
- **DateTested:** Date of test  
- **Cost** of the drug

### Load dataset 
To load the dataset into Data Scientist Workbench, run the following cell. It will download and unzip the dataset.

result.msg:
1. Read drug data files

Drug dataset

As can be seen, the data set contains information about the age and gender of each patient along with Blood Pressure, Cholesterol, Sodium and Potassium levels. Finally, we have information about the drug the patient responded well to.

The dataset is in the form of two json files, stored in a directory. The first json file is related to year 2014, and the second one is for year 2015. You can download the json files from here

Here is a sample row of druginfo2015.json:

{ “Ent#“:12, “Age”:34, “Gender”:“F”, “BP”:“HIGH”, “Cholesterol”:“NORMAL”, “Sodium”:0.667775, “Potassium”:0.034782, “Drug”:“drugY”, “Cost”:“1.981,09”, “DateTested”:“1980-10-11T10:10:20” }

Variables in the data set are :

  • Ent# which represents patient ID
  • Age of each patient
  • Gender of each patient
  • BP - Blood Pressure of each patient
  • Cholesterol levels
  • Sodium levels
  • Potassium levels
  • Drug the patient responded well to
  • DateTested: Date of test
  • Cost of the drug

Load dataset

To load the dataset into Data Scientist Workbench, run the following cell. It will download and unzip the dataset.

Archive:  /resources/data/sparklingdataset.zip
  inflating: /resources/data/sparklingdata/data/sampleDataDir/customers.csv  
  inflating: /resources/data/sparklingdata/data/sampleDataDir/drugInfo2014.json  
  inflating: /resources/data/sparklingdata/data/sampleDataDir/drugInfo2015.json  
  inflating: /resources/data/sparklingdata/data/sampleDocsDir/Events.doc  
  inflating: /resources/data/sparklingdata/data/sampleDocsDir/News.pdf

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Read in dataset (JSON data files) 
In this tutorial, we will use the __Sparkling.data__ library to examine data profiles, view value distributions, and assess data quality. In next cell, __Sparkling.data__ helps __sqlContext__ to read all json files, merge them and discover the schema of dataset.   
The source directory __/resources/data/sparklingdata/data/sampleDataDir__ contains two JSON files of drug data and it may contains other files as well.

File format discovery will load the most occuring type of data by default. In this case, the JSON drug data will be loaded.
Now, run the following cell to read the json files from sample Data Directory.

__Notice:__ You can give a directory with folders/subfolders containing mixed types of files. Sparkling.data discovers your file types and returns a dataframe representing the most occurring type. It will also gives visibility into the variety and ability to choose specific types.

result.msg:
Read in dataset (JSON data files)

In this tutorial, we will use the Sparkling.data library to examine data profiles, view value distributions, and assess data quality. In next cell, Sparkling.data helps sqlContext to read all json files, merge them and discover the schema of dataset.
The source directory /resources/data/sparklingdata/data/sampleDataDir contains two JSON files of drug data and it may contains other files as well.

File format discovery will load the most occuring type of data by default. In this case, the JSON drug data will be loaded.
Now, run the following cell to read the json files from sample Data Directory.

Notice: You can give a directory with folders/subfolders containing mixed types of files. Sparkling.data discovers your file types and returns a dataframe representing the most occurring type. It will also gives visibility into the variety and ability to choose specific types.

paragraphs.text:
%md
Lets look at our data now:

result.msg: Lets look at our data now:

paragraphs.text:
%md
# 2. Discover data types from the input data frame
First, we run inferred type on input data frame and print discovered data frame schema. 
We can print discovered data types. For more info about each field and its data type run the following cell. You can see for example, __Cost__ includes three data types: [Short, String, Byte]. It also shows the precentage of each data type, that is, Short: 0.166 %, String: 0.43 % and Byte: 0.4 %
      
#### Note: see  that 'Cost' column inferred as 'Short' because of its highest percentage and 'DateTested' column inferred as 'Timestamp'

result.msg:
2. Discover data types from the input data frame

First, we run inferred type on input data frame and print discovered data frame schema.
We can print discovered data types. For more info about each field and its data type run the following cell. You can see for example, Cost includes three data types: [Short, String, Byte]. It also shows the precentage of each data type, that is, Short: 0.166 %, String: 0.43 % and Byte: 0.4 %

Note: see that 'Cost' column inferred as 'Short' because of its highest percentage and 'DateTested' column inferred as 'Timestamp'

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
options = {'extractFields':True}
dfInfered = eu.inferTypes(df, options)
dfInfered.printSchema()
eu.printTypes(dfInfered)

%md
# 3. Reveal and fix bad data exist in the input data frame
We run _inferrred type_ with __revealNA__ option and show the result data frame. The result dataset is all rows in dataframe that has bad values.
__mode__ in option can be "any" or "all". 
- "any" is to show the row if any fields has bad value.
- "all" if all of fields are bad values.

result.msg:
3. Reveal and fix bad data exist in the input data frame

We run inferrred type with revealNA option and show the result data frame. The result dataset is all rows in dataframe that has bad values.
mode in option can be “any” or “all”.

  • “any” is to show the row if any fields has bad value.
  • “all” if all of fields are bad values.

paragraphs.text:
%md
Now that we found out that 'Cost' column has bad data, let's use Sparkling.Data to detect these values and fix them.  
In order to fix it, run the inferred types again with proper options. We use spanish locale with grouping to fix 'Cost' column data. 
Notice that 'Cost' column type now changed from __Short__ to __Float__

result.msg:
Now that we found out that 'Cost' column has bad data, let's use Sparkling.Data to detect these values and fix them.
In order to fix it, run the inferred types again with proper options. We use spanish locale with grouping to fix 'Cost' column data.
Notice that 'Cost' column type now changed from Short to Float

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
options = {'locale': 'es', 'groupingUsed': True, 'extractFields': True}
drugDfForAnalysis = eu.inferTypes(df, options)
drugDfForAnalysis.printSchema()
eu.printTypes(drugDfForAnalysis)

%md
# 4. Profile your Data
We can run __profile__ on input data frame to generate profile information. It help us to understand the type, range, distribution and some stats about diferrent columns of our data.
It shows some info about:   

"StatsNames" : e.g. "count","mean","min","max"  
"inferred_type": It shows data type, e.g. String   
"Bins": Bins range for numerical columns  
"Values": Bins frequency  

_Notic:_ __eu.profile__ counts number of _null_s and then put -Double.MaxValue in Bins as first element. So in bins you could see -1.7976931348623157E308 which is (-Double.MaxValue). For example, bins created for Cost column as [-1.7976931348623157E308,11.0,51.0,9...]. So based on this first Bin value NaN-NaN count is defined.

result.msg:
4. Profile your Data

We can run profile on input data frame to generate profile information. It help us to understand the type, range, distribution and some stats about diferrent columns of our data.
It shows some info about:

“StatsNames” : e.g. “count”,“mean”,“min”,“max”
“inferred_type”: It shows data type, e.g. String
“Bins”: Bins range for numerical columns
“Values”: Bins frequency

Notic: eu.profile counts number of _null_s and then put -Double.MaxValue in Bins as first element. So in bins you could see -1.7976931348623157E308 which is (-Double.MaxValue). For example, bins created for Cost column as [-1.7976931348623157E308,11.0,51.0,9…]. So based on this first Bin value NaN-NaN count is defined.

# 6. Analyze your data

Now, we can easily use the clean data to create a decision tree. To analyze the cleaned data, first, we read the saved data.

paragraphs.text:
%md
To understand the data better, we look at the distribution of the data set broken down by the drug.

result.msg: To understand the data better, we look at the distribution of the data set broken down by the drug.

paragraphs.text:
%md
To classify our data, we have to select train and test dataset.

result.msg: To classify our data, we have to select train and test dataset.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
pdf = dfSaved.toPandas()
X = pdf[['Age','Potassium','Sodium']]
Y = pdf['Drug']

%md
To classify our data, we use Decision Trees package of [scikit-learn](http://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/tree.html).  Decision Tree is a non-parametric supervised learning method used for classification and regression. The goal is to create a model that predicts the value of a target variable (drug in this case) by learning simple decision rules inferred from the data features.

result.msg: To classify our data, we use Decision Trees package of scikit-learn. Decision Tree is a non-parametric supervised learning method used for classification and regression. The goal is to create a model that predicts the value of a target variable (drug in this case) by learning simple decision rules inferred from the data features.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
from sklearn import tree
clf = tree.DecisionTreeClassifier()
clf = clf.fit(X, Y)
print clf.predict([[28, 0.072289,0.82778]])

result.msg: [u'drugC']

paragraphs.text:
%md

You need pydot and graphviz packages to visualize a decision tree. graphviz package facilitates the creation and rendering of graph descriptions in the DOT language of the Graphviz graph.

Notice: Graphviz and Pydot are not currently available in Zeppelin and you may see error running the following cells. We are still working on that.

result.msg:
You need pydot and graphviz packages to visualize a decision tree. graphviz package facilitates the creation and rendering of graph descriptions in the DOT language of the Graphviz graph.

Notice: Graphviz and Pydot are not currently available in Zeppelin and you may see error running the following cells. We are still working on that.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
from sklearn import tree
from sklearn.externals.six import StringIO 
import graphviz
from graphviz import Digraph
feature_names=X.columns.tolist()
target_names=Y.unique().astype(str)
dot_data = StringIO() 
tree.export_graphviz(clf, out_file=dot_data,  
                         feature_names=feature_names,  
                         class_names=target_names,  
                         filled=True, rounded=True,  
                         special_characters=True)

%md
To visualize the graph, we need pydot package to generate a PNG/PDF file (or any other supported file type)
